May primary election important dates
April 4: Deadline to register to vote
April 5: Absentee voting by mail begins
April 5: Early in-person voting beings
April 30: Deadline to request absentee ballot
April early in-person voting hours
April 5-8: 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
April 11-15: 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
April 18-22: 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
April 25-29: 8:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m.
April 30: 8:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
May early in-person voting hours
May 1: 1:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m.
May 2: 8:00 a.m. - 2:00 p.m.
How to vote by mail
The deadline to request an absentee ballot is three days before the election.

More:Democrats running for Ohio U.S. Senate seat held their first debate.

Following is the schedule for early in-person voting in Marion County:
• April 5-8, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
• April 11-15, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
• April 18-22, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
• April 25-29, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.
• April 30, 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.
• May 1, 1 to 5 p.m.
• May 2, 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.
Absentee ballot applications are still being accepted at the board of elections office.

Fill out the online application, print it and mail it to your local county board of elections
Call the board of elections and request an application is mailed to you
Write a letter to county board of elections with your full name, date of birth, and address where you are registered to vote.

In Marion County there will be a Republican primary for county commissioner with incumbent Commissioner Ken Stiverson being challenged by County Coroner Dr. Mark Davis and current Marion City Council member Jason Schaber.
The early voting center in Marion County is located at the Marion County Board of Elections office on the ground floor of the Marion County Building, 222 W. Center St. in downtown Marion.
Ohio House, Ohio Senate and State Central Committee races will not appear on the May primary ballots due to Ohio Supreme Court's March invalidation of the redistricting plan.
Absentee ballots can be obtained at the board of elections office, the U.S. Post Office branch on Barks Road, or on the board of elections website www.boe.ohio.gov/marion.
Despite all of the confusion around this year's primary election, Ohio is still set to have an election on May 3 and early voting started on Tuesday, April 5.

We have compiled some resources to help with early voting and to provide more information about candidates and races happening around the state.
Absentee ballots may be returned in person to the Board of Elections office or placed in the secure drop box by 7:30 p.m. on May 3.
For information, go to the board of elections website www.boe.ohio.gov/marion or call 740-223-4090.

Absentee ballots should be dropped off no later than 7:30 p.m. on Election Day.
